posts.cooked: Our team has been using the limelight’s default calibration for this year. I could calibrate it by following limelight’s ChArUco camera calibration, and I’ve even tried calibrating with this. I only had time to get around 40 valid snapshots, but I didn’t go through with it because we were able to work well with the default calibration. Would putting the effort to get more snapshots and calibrate the limelight properly be worth it? How much of a difference would a custom calibration make?

posts.name: Tinnittin
posts.cooked:
How are you using the limelight? Are you “servoing” or doing pose estimation?

Check out the Why Does This Matter section here:

Why Does This Matter?

We use pose estimation; we don’t do any “servoing”. The main reason for exploring this is because our estimated pose jitters a lot (upto 0.6 meters off) during rotation. We resolve this by scaling our standard deviation by our rotational velocity and tag area. I’m wondering if calibrating the limelight would be help this.

posts.name: Drew Williams
posts.cooked: If you are doing 3d estimation, I would argue calibration is a strict requirement. The differences in lenses between individual cameras are significant enough that you need to.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: I moved to California just for districts

posts.custom_user_title: I moved to California just for districts

posts.name: viggy96

posts.cooked: Thank you very much, I’ll definitely prioritize this more. We are also using a printed paper taped to a board for this, but seeing how important it seems, is it recommended to invent in a proper board? The one in limelight documentation seems expensive, is there a cheaper or better board anywhere else. If not, we can just buy the one limelight recommends.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
These will be fine:

https://www.etsy.com/listing/1820746969/charuco-calibration-target

I got the small ones, but I’m sure the big ones are good too.
